I recently moved to downtown and this was a spot that all my friends said to check out. It did not disappoint. I got the big Jim biscuit for dinner which came with a generously sized portion of fried chicken and plenty of gravy. I also ordered the Mac n cheese. I do not advise you should order both if you are eating alone. Simply not enough space in a human stomach.  The staff was very friendly and while they were only moderately busy service was very prompt. There is plenty of parking on the street. I will definitely be back.
The food is amazing, drinks are delicious!  Only detractors are the 90% outside seats meaning a battle w flies and the occasional monster truck.  Kid friendly - we'll be back!!

Wow.  So I've been hearing about this place for a while.  I always looked for it when I passed it on my way down Roosevelt but always seemed to miss it.  I practically smacked myself in the forehead when we arrived today.  I felt stupid, but then again, there are some places I just can't see until I plan to stop there.  It took some convincing to get my husband to give a place other than his favourite Joe's Diner a chance for a delicious (post hangover) brunch/breakfast a chance.  We got there a little early due to it being their last brunch weekend before summer and I am paranoid of crowds and hipsters.  We arrived and found ourselves seats under an umbrella in the shade.  We got some water from the cooler and perused the menu and specials.  After some deliberating (sunrise sandwich or holy puerco?) and discussion (welcome breakfast has no meat -- I need my protein at breakfast), he went with the special boudin breakfast and I got the holy puerco.  We both had fresh squeezed ojs and beignets.  It was worth it.  Dear goodness I have not tasted pork jowl cruncy bits like those ever (and their meat is provided by meat shop and shreiners!).  The combination of flavors on the puerco thing was just delicious.  And the hashbrowns were fresh and not too crispy and not overpowering and flavorful.  I kind of wanted some sour cream to go with the flavors and make them like a crunchy baked potato.  The beignets are not as fluffy as the ones I remember in New Orleans but definitely will satisfy this girls desire for fried dough.  They are yummy and powdered and you must be careful or the sugar will make you cough.  The honey is also oh so good.  The husband very much enjoyed his boudin special and it was gone very quickly.  He said it was all very tasty and he was glad we braved the heat for the opportunity to try the breakfast before it is gone.  We also got a hurricane to share at the very end.  It tastes like juice, or sunshine in a cup.  But it does pack a punch.  I felt that drink (the few sips I had) by the time we got back home.  And then I crashed in a delicious food coma.
For some reason, when I think of iconic parts of Phoenix, Welcome Diner comes to mind. The place itself for me feels nostalgic. Anyone visiting downtown Phoenix has got to stop by.

We came here with my brother and sister in laws they came into town late at night and this place was  the only place open where we could chill and have good food.. everyone loved it my husband and I had the burger it was very unique we definitely will be coming back forget IHOP and come to welcome diner!!

OH!  MY!  GOD!  I don't understand how anyone could give this place less than 5 stars... Food is incredible, staff are friendly and welcoming, and the drinks are delicious, especially the Hurricane. I had the Carrie pulled pork sandwich and I can honestly say it was one of the best meals I have ever had. EVER!  Don't listen to these winey bitches who give three stars... They obviously don't understand good food and good service. Would eat here every day if I didn't live so far away. Wow

I went on a late night Thursday and ordered the poutine fries. This has been on my list of places to try for some time. The food was great, huge plate and a good price point. I didn't have a drink. I had to use the restroom and it was teeeeny tiny and kind of dirty, not a fan of that. Other than that it's a good place to chat with friends, we sat outside and it was really cold but the heaters were not on.

The guy who served us here was so kind and attentive to us.  They have homemade ginger beer which, IF you like that kind of thing, is very good!  The menu is pretty limited because it's a VERY small space but we all had some biscuit sandwiches and they were really nice!  Hot and fresh!

Got there at around midnight. Waited patiently to order the famous chicken biscuit sandwiches and poutin fries.  Unfortunately they were completely out of fried chicken and gravy.  Our bad luck turned into good luck because we had to go with other options.  Turns out the po boys and burgers are amazing!  Don't be afraid to go outside of your ordering comfort zone here.  Don't guzzle your drink too quickly,  it takes a while to get your food after you order.  It's well worth the wait though, and the people watching & music make the time go by faster.  We will return!  Now we're craving that fried chicken and gravy even more.  We will get there earlier on future visits.  Btw open till 2am with full bar.  Btw don't fear sitting next to strangers,  picnic style table seating on a first come first serve basis.

This place is amazing, great food, great atmosphere. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that the food is a bit pricey.  But don't let that stop you from trying it at least once. (Though I think if you go once, you'll go back. ;)

I drive by this place all the time and I never stopped cuz all the hipsters, but so glad I took a nice stroll from mi amigas casa to do so bcus this place is super. I got the eggplant parm special. The breading for the eggplant was on point but I realized I'm not a fan of soggy bread so that kills it cuz you need the sauce. Supper yummy sandy though! I also tried the Bumble Bee. It is served on a biscuit (so warm/so soft) fried chix w/a bourbon mustard sauce, mmmm bread and butter pickles and sits in honey all fancy. This is a tasty eat....although be warned the mustard saucy is a tad kicky w/the bourbon, was a suprise for me! Anyways so worth going, open late and I love eating outside picnic table style.

Just an awesome place to eat and chill with friends or  bring your family for a late dinner for outdoor seating :) all food choices are unique and absolutely delicious. You have to try the biscuit sandwiches!! Their gravy is like no other! I loved it and I'm not a big gravy fan.
Fabulous jack fruit po boy, and fried green tomato sandwich. This is also one of my favorite spots for cocktails!

Love welcome diner!  The PB&B (Peanut Butter and Bacon) burger is absolutely delicious (if you like Peanut butter of course). The meat is always cooked very well, the ingredients fresh, and a great mix of flavors.  Also on my favorite list is Poutine Fries. Fries, topped with Gravy.
Me and my girlfriend got the pb&b burger and no way Jose a couple days ago and wow these burgers are hands down the best we ever had and the coleslaw was awesome props to the cooks!
Just left an awesome dinner at Welcome Diner. Staff is beyond friendly, and the food was delicious. We're new to Phoenix, and we'll definitely be back often. Thanks yall!
Yummy! I got the fried chicken macaron & no way Jose burger. To drink I got the Hurricane. Everything so good!!!
The pulled Jack Fruit was magnificent! Super convenient and a nice home feel.

Delicious food, good service, and reasonable prices - especially for happy hour. Only complaint is the atmosphere - being right by a street with cars whizzing by isn't the ideal vibe. Overall though, great place! Will definitely return.
Order one of everything, I insist. Worry about the pocket change later. You're welcome, in advance.

Came here for dinner with my boyfriend and the food was so delicious! Everyone that worked there was extremely friendly and outgoing. Only downside is the restaurant is outside and very minimal seating inside. Other than that, it's a great place to eat in downtown phoenix!

I took my coworkers to the new location last night before a comedy show. We live on the northwest side so aren't able to get downtown often. I was actually worried that the new location would not have the same character as the old location....well it absolutely does. When we arrived the place was full besides the bar, so we sat at the bar which is actually an open kitchen and we were able to watch the cooking of all of the food which we enjoyed. The Paloma cocktail was so good! I love tequila and grapefruit so it was a great combination. I ordered the big Jim for my meal. It was a biscuit with fried chicken, gravy and cheddar aka heart attack on a plate but so well worth it.  I feel like the service was much better this time around and the food came out fresh and fast.My coworkers and I really enjoyed our meal and will go back when downtown again.

Best night out possible! Cocktails are all hand crafted perfectly.  Staff is super passionate and proud of the product.  My boyfriend loves the peanut butter burger and I had the fried green tomato sandwich.  The corn relish with the fried tomato made me wish for a jar to take home and have at with a spoon.
Great ambiance.  Outdoor seating under stringed lights was neat.  Food was ok.  If you are in the mood for unhealthy food, go for it.
Great burgers, but we waited 45 minutes to get our food ... That's crazy.  Kitchen is way too small, and service people were friendly but clueless.
Some of the best food in downtown! The poutine was wonderful, great ambience, the bumble bee biscuit was out of this world! If you've never been here, you're cheating yourself

I love this place. I am fairly certain that I would give it 5 stars if I wasn't a vegetarian.  My meat loving pals are obsessed with the Big Jim (best fried chicken sandwich smothered in gravy, topped with bacon and cheese)--even makes me want to give up morals for a bite!    The folks behind the counter are always super friendly and chill.  They have drink specials and daily food specials that are mouthwatering!  I love the vegan poboy.  Fried avocado like no other!    I think I might be biased, but I do love me some Welcome Diner (but I can't eat here too much or I'll end up as big as a house!)

Okay so I went to Welcome Diner this morning after seeing my friends IG post of his food a week ago. Met a friend and we sat inside was greeted by the entire staff including Wayne and Justin the Cook, our server was super cool too. Ordered the Sunrise Sandwich- A Biscuit for a bun with scrambled eggs, Cheese, Arugala and per the recommendation of our server added Chorizo....BOMB DOT COM I can't wait to go back and try some of the other things on the menu...just go and eat it's worth it!.

This is my favorite place in town. Their food is out of this world. Im a vegetarian and they have so many options for me. My favorite things on the menu are: Mac n cheese with Brussel sprouts and the jack fries. Their fried green tomato sandwich is phenomenal as well.  I highly recommend this place to anyone.

[Other reviews of Payton Curry's chef-in-residence at Welcome Diner: http://www.yelp.com/biz/payton-curry-at-welcome-diner-phoenix]  THE VEGETARIAN ANGLE  When you can date a review to the exact day (and with good reason), you know that you're in a special place.  We ate at Payton Curry's pop-up restaurant at the Welcome Diner last night, April 19, 2011, and the following is what we ate, but you may have a different menu on Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday evenings from 5pm-close through July 4.  Chef, I hear, tries to keep it real and keep it local and fresh when sourcing his menu, so it changes each week.  McClendon's Select was mentioned more than once.  (PRICE NOTE:  On Tuesdays from 10pm-close, the menu is 1/2 price to be sure Curry exhausts his fresh produce and meats.)  Welcome Diner was serving about 12 people when we arrived, 6 at the inside counter and three couples outside dotting the front yard, set up with a picnic table, a sawhorse, some two tops, and glass tabletop lanterns.  The food came out quickly, and our gracious and knowledgeable server asked if we'd like our dishes as they were prepared or in courses. We opted for the former.  My darling dining partner and I shared all four dishes.  THOSE DAMN GREEN BEANS We started with green beans, as crisp as they were picked, with just one tip snapped off, just like my grandmother taught me.  These were served with a citrus creme fraiche and some recently picked tarragon.  I always love dairy with tarragon, and this dish, served cool (not cold) if I remember, was dusted with local bee pollen, granular bits that taste of honey and something else and melt on your tongue.  MOZZARELLA The menu insists there's basil in this tangential rendition of caprese -- and there probably is -- but the takeaway message from this panko-encrusted slab of mozzarella with the sweetest tomatoes I've eaten is a sweet-n-sour burst with every olive oily bite.  A standout appetizer.  GNOCCHI If you're like me, when you've eaten or prepared gnocchi before, you assume they get plopped into the boiling salted water before the plump up and rise to the surface.  Not so fast, Barilla Boy.  Payton Curry's gnocchi, I believe, are (dry?) pan-seared on both sides,   keeping all the doughy, gummy deliciousness often lost in the water.  The madeira wine and cream reduction here smothers the pillowy gnocchi and tooth-tender walnuts and squiggly good morel mushrooms in a way that makes you close your eyes, shut off your hearing, and attempt to pour all of your sensory energy into taste and smell.  When eating this dish, I more than once covered my face with my hand to shield what may have been unflattering facial pangs of ecstasy.    LEMON CURD We struggled to choose this dessert over the Strawberry Olive Oil Cake and Strawberry Malt, but we got our strawberry fix as the second layer in this delectable parfait, topped with the airiest foamy meringue, and served in a mason jar.  The macerated strawberries made you want to relive childhood and replace mom's jelly with Payton's strawberries to accompany Laura Scudder in your PB&J sandwich.  We clanged spoons at the bottom of the jar for the last bit of bee pollen.  $62 with tax and tip.  We didn't bring a BYOB wine but would next time.  (The $13 corkage fee seems high, but there ought to be an explanation for that.)  Everyone working in the tiny dinette and serving the tables outside had huge smiles and loads of enthusiasm for what they were contributing to the Garfield neighborhood and to the downtown culinary scene.  Others are taking notice, too. Michelle Laudig (former restaurant critic at Phoenix New Times) and Aaron Chamberlin of St. Francis both dropped in during our dinner.  I worry about the AZ heat baking the charm out of patio dining in May,  June, and July for Chef Curry, but I hope to return in April...maybe on a Tuesday at 10pm for half-price eats.  Other reviews of Payton Curry's chef-in-residence at Welcome Diner: http://www.yelp.com/biz/payton-curry-at-welcome-diner-phoenix

Great food, great service, great atmosphere! We had the veggie burger and the Welcome Burger. Both were amazing! The fried avocado was out of this world.   We will definitely be going back. I highly recommend this unique little gem in Downtown Phoenix.

This place rocks!! Definitely a great spot for a comfort food fix...with a twist. We tried the happy hour menu and were impressed that the portions were huge! On our list to try was the "Little Birdy," "poutine fries," and "jackfruit BBQ fries." That hit crunchy, hearty and unusually delicious - really though we accidentally got an order of the regular pork BBQ fries when we tried the jackfruit. The service was fast and friendly. We loved the laid back atmosphere accented by the neon light of the diner. You HAVE TO check this spot out!

I had always heard of this place and finally decided to come and check it out. I had a busser greet me and welcome me in because I was a dinner. I had a cashier give me a quick run down on how the restaurant works, the chefs finished my meal in a timely manner, and the dish washer did a great job on cleaning my plate and utensils. If there's something that can make me loose my appetite and make me not even bother touching the my food is seeing old food from a previous customer still on my plate and silverware.   I got the No Way Jose burger which was delicious but small.  I finished it in 5 bites.

So loved this quirky little diner.  Ate here last night and everything was DELISH!    I had the fried chicken sandwich , man oh man chicken doesn't get crunchier than that!  Also had a gin tonic made with their small batch tonic syrup.  My boyfriend had an amazing burger and as thought that wasn't enough we shared the Mac & cheese, so light and airy, wonderful.  If you are on a diet his is not the place to visit lol. But, if you want amazing comfort food at a great price you've found your spot.
I live for their jackfruit fries. A little pricy but worth it, especially if you can make happy hour.

Updating my review for Welcome Diner after having been there a few times now! I will admit that if it weren't for my boyfriend who decided after the first time that he loved it, I probably wouldn't have gone back.  Anyways - I'm a huge fan of their fries, first and foremost. I get them every time. They're the thinner shoestring variety & come with a different kind of delicious creamy dipping sauce, rather than just ketchup. You can get them topped with jackfruit, pulled pork, or poutine. With one of the toppings, it's basically the size of a meal.  I also really like the bumblebee sandwich. The fried chicken is one of the best and it tastes great on their biscuit with some honey!  My boyfriend swears by the jackfruit po'boy & for good reason. It's really a tasty vegetarian option, which is commonly difficult to find at most places. While he's not vegetarian, it's his go-to option, and the first time he had it, he said that it tasted very similar to pulled pork!  Also, if you're a fan of fish, try out the fish po'boy. The tarter sauce that comes on it is smooth & creamy and balances out the tart coleslaw. My favorite part about it is that it's much lighter than the fried chicken.  They open later on in the day and are open until 2am. It's our #1 choice for a late night bite!

Incredible. I traveled to pheonix for the weekend and ate here late-night twice. Maybe it was the condition I was in after a concert, but I believe this is the best burger I've ever had. Excellent patio too-- a real hipster's delight. GO HERE NOW

I have to give this place 5 stars, due to the delicious, unusual food options, as well as the ambiance that made me jump through time to yesteryear and relive memories that never happened but that I always wished had happened.
Been here two times now for comic con rest place to chill and yummy food ! Burgers and smothered frys

We ate lunch there on a weekday in early 10/04.  The Welcome is a restored 1930s diner and seating consists of just nine (counter) seats.  It's definitely cramped, but that means you'll get to converse with your neighbors.  The menu is quite limited, although the food was good.  However, they don't give you plates and the food was *very* greasy (our sandwiches came on a piece of waxed paper and the grease quickly soaked through the paper onto the counter).  The other thing I didn't like, was that you had to *buy* (bottled) water if that was your drink of choice.  They had a cook, a helper and a waitress working in a VERY tiny space....the waitress was o.k., but the cook and helper were pretty friendly.  It seemed that everyone but us was a "regular", which was kind of fun; we had an amusing conversation with the three guys (co-workers) who sat nearest us.

We are from Oakland, the land of hipster restaurants. This one is super cool and the nighttime weather in Phoenix makes sitting outside that much better than the cold nights of Oakland. The food was amazing. I had their bumblebee biscuit, watermelon salad, and homemade fruit punch. It was all more than delicious and was extremely fresh. The ambiance really sets it apart and makes the whole experience worth it. Theres something about eating good food on a warm evening, sitting at a picnic table under twinkie lights, an catching up with friends that really makes an verage night special and memorable. Thanks Welcome Diner. The staff are very friendly as well.

Really amazing food and generous portions! I used to come to here with my boyfriend for burgers since it's right next to my house, but then we decided to go vegetarian because of pollution, cruelty, health ect. and had to stop eating here because their were hardly any veggie options and we were never given a straight answer about whether any of the products were local. Vegetables aside, this place is definitely worth going to if you want good food and want to meet great people.

I finally get a chance to taste "the bumble bee" that I've seen on the yelp tease pics. Why did it have to be so good? I'm supposed to be 80% gluten free gosh darn! I'm going to have to increase my weekly indulgences to 2 1/2 because Phoenix makes being good very difficult. I'll say the mustard competes with the pickles, but doesn't mess up the sandwich. Oh do these people know exactly what they are doing with the honey on top! Honey and pickles on one sandwich together in perfect harmony (swoon). Chik-fool-a can kiss my diversity after this sandwich. Not that I've eaten there since --you know-- but it was something to miss. My sister had the "big Jim" and man is that a lot of gravy. Nothing was wrong in that sandwich other than ordering it with a side which would make you glutton of the year. (She ordered the Mac n'cheese with it and I hope she never reads this).  Don't do it, your stomach can only expand so much! To conclude: yum.

Here's the deal. I want to totally love this, but frankly, Phoenix is still missing the traditional diner, even when it's housed in an authentic diner. I was hoping this would be the epic college hang-out, but it's too expensive for that. An 8 buck burger is three dollars away from a night out for a collegiate. 5 bucks for a 12 oz plastic cup pour, even a good draft, is still not in that ballpark. Actually, it's close to ballpark pricing. Knock off at least a buck.  And 4 dollars for a very small portion of collard greens will not bring me back to eat it.  I ordered the most expensive meal because I wanted the food experience. Their PB and B burger is exceptional, peanut butter with burger sounds weird, but it's damn tasty and good Schrieber's bacon(also used at Bill Johnsons Big Apple for less dinero). It's the highest price burger at $12.50. I also had the previously mentioned collard greens and a 7 buck Hurricane, tasty and well-mixed, almost at price point correctly with such good ingredients.  Three items and with tip, over $28.00.  This falls into the realm of special event for me, and that's a shame as the folks running the kitchen, taking orders, owners are ALL great and the service was really casual yet efficient.  I would love to see something like a whiskey and soda for $4.00, discounted pitchers of beer, maybe even a discount for bringing in your own coffee cup or dishes as there really is a lot of plastic waste coming out of there.  Sure, I'll be back, and for what it is(an amazing restoration of a wonderful place with a killer patio)I'm glad it's here. I'll have whatever is on special now, and skip the sides, though the fries with gravy could be killer with cheese curds a la  poutine.   Yet still I wait for the college hang-out.

I love the Welcome Diner  Most of what we had was awesome. I'd been having day dreams of the PB + B burger (no cheese), and it was everything I hoped for. Nice burger cooked a perfect medium rare. So glad they went with chunky PB, and loads of it  We split the Welcome fries topped with Kiltlifter braised pulled pork and housemade Carolina BBQ sauce. Was exactly what you'd expect, nothing fancy, but really tasty  The only miss was the Fried Avacado. Plain and flavorless, really just a vehicle for a nice dipping sauce. Now, if they did a fried chunky spicy onion heavy guacamole, they might have something  Also have been in for brunch, and the Holy Puerco is amazing

My expectations got dumped on after I came to Welcome Diner. We came for some passable late night grub. Instead we got kickass grub and some really nice drinks.  Of course we come on a Tuesday - clearly the best day because it was happy hour all day. Between my group we had a Hurricane, Gin and Tonic, Whiskey Sour, a Little Birdy, and an order of Poutine.  Happy hour drinks at $5-6, you don't expect much. But these staples actually hold their own against bars that would sell theirs for $10+. The gin and tonic was refreshing with the addition of lime juice. The Whiskey Sour had a nice balanced tart flavor from the fruit. And the Hurricane was basically alcoholic juicy goodness.  From the food, literally comfort food at its finest. The Little Birdy - that in house biscuit, plus that awesome succulent fried chicken and slice of cheese - some of the best $5 I've ever spent. And the Poutine is glorious. Probably some of the most conservative, it's close to the traditional sense of just gravy and cheese, but they opt to use a peppery country style gravy and cheddar cheese. It's makes you feel a little worse and better at the same time.  The fact that this place is basically in the middle of a sketchy neighborhood actually added to the appeal for me. It's a bright spot with outdoor seating that makes you want to have a good time. Can't wait to come back.
Cool diner, poutine is good but shredded cheese and white gravy is very non traditional.

I have been here twice and liked both experiences.  It's a cool little hip little diner: nothing fancy.  I have not been on the inside, but I like the outside tables a lot because I brought my dog both times.  I had the chicken sandwich with honey (it's name escapes me, but it had something to do with bees), and the buffalo chicken sandwich on my second visit.  My sister had some kind of a grit cake that was awesome and my mom had pulled pork with slaw - all were on a home made biscuit.  Unless you are really hungry, you might choose to share.  we also had house made ginger beer (delightful) and lemonade.  Great little place.
Great little spot with wonderful fries and biscuit sandwiches. Yummy!

Had the No Way Jose medium rare and it was unbelievably delicious- Gouda, beef, arugula, muenster, and some 'charred jalapeo relish'. Could've easily devoured a second one, it was that good.    Liked the chill atmosphere and the staff were all super friendly.  When I next pass through Phoenix you better believe I'm hitting this place up again!

Love this place..i love the casual outdoor setting that is especially nice as the temperature dips. The menu is full of great items but I'm a sucker for the bumblebee biscuit. The mac and cheese is always a hit and the added options like chorizo can give it more kick. Great beverages and my preferred cocktail would be the hurricane drink. Can't wait to go again and again

I've only been here for brunch once....it's the shit.   They had me with the "ATTENTION BALLERS, no $50 or $100 BILLS, PLEASE"  (I'll post a picture)  Basically my kind of place already.   It's a tiny place inside thus the 4 stars but they have a nice patio area with benches, tables and ect.   Food is like some concoction of amazingness. I can't even remember what I had, but it was tasty and full of god knows what, pretty much everything and anything one can think of. They also sell beers and stuff.   It's located in the garfield district right off roosevelt.   I heard it was once a food truck that parked and now it rests.   Go here for something awesome and different.

What can I say? Mostly EVERYTHING here is housemade, and to die for. Its some seriously unhealthy southern diner food but my oh my, it is delicious. The only caviot is that the hurricanes and other drinks don't seem near as strong as they used to.

I liked it.  Pros: loved the atmosphere, the ambiance, and the food.  It was downtown fun and hipster.  The food I ordered, fried green tomato sandwich and the big Jim, were very flavorful and tasty!  Con's: Big Jim needed more gravy!  It was so good but after 2 bites the gravy was gone and I was left with dry biscuit on awesome fried chicken. So the two bites I had...great!  The rest....a little dry.  And I hate to say it, but it took 45 minutes to get our food, 30 to get a single drink order.  This killlllss me!! Buuut it is a small place.    Verdict:  Glad I went and had a great time!  Will I be back?  Nope.  Once was enough

After having lunch at 4pm and being super hungry after leaving a concert, the Welcome Diner was just what I needed at 11pm.  I asked for the sunrise biscuit but subbed Brussels sprouts for the biscuit.  Chorizo, fried egg, aioli deliciousness.  They also had a yellow watermelon ginger beer that was phenomenal.  Open late, eclectic, unique, and scrumptious.  What a treat, Phoenix!
Simple review. I will definitely be back... Tomorrow! Just look at the pictures. Phenomenal.

If you're looking for the unique, quirky, off the beaten path side of Phoenix, come to the Welcome Diner.  With 9 stools around a bar near a hot kitchen, it is a small place with a lot to see.  The cooks are very friendly and talkative, and will give you their opinion on their dishes if prompted.  Try the classic cheeseburger, fries, and soda - it's definitely a favorite.  The Welcome Diner is definitely small, but worth the wait (if there even is one.)  It is truly a treasure to the historic Garfield district.

Great little place... Let me start by saying, they make their own tonic water for their gin (or vodka) & tonic. They have a small menu of really exceptional dishes, beverages and a couple deserts.  Great atmosphere, and friendly staff.  Definitely try the beignets, with either traditional powdered sugar, honey or "dirty" with peanut butter and their own preserves.

Maaaan, this place is tiny. Once you get past the fact that there's nine seats, and the griddle takes up about 30% of the building, you realize that this is one of those special little haunts that makes cities cool. It's totally off the beaten path, but just three blocks from First Friday mayhem. You could drive right by and never even notice it (I had about 15 times).   Inside it's surprisingly sparce, considering it's about 75 square feet. There's no AC, just a few well-placed fans on full blast. I went in the middle of the afternoon in July and felt pretty comfortable, especially considering the kitchen IS the place.   And the food... you want greasy, delicious, messy, rich, heavenly sinful pig-out fare? What's that? You want it at dirt cheap prices and with friendly service? It's perfect. The cheeseburger is oozing cheddar, the fries are sliced about four seconds before they go into the fryer and they have french toast in a cup. Need I say more?

The BEST after bar food! I never knew how much I needed biscuits and gravely in my life until we were told (yes, told) we needed to go here. Now my husband and I ride our bikes here often for dinner.  Can't wait to see what they do with their new location!

Wow my friend found them on yelp what amazing food had welcome burger excellent.   Also had the corn dog appetizers wow the ladies I was with said it's the best hurricane they have ever had.  Great job guys a definite go to location for everyone. ..

What I love most about Welcome Diner is that when you are there, it doesn't feel as though you are in Phoenix.  The menu is good ol' Southern comfort food with a twist; they have Deep Eddy alcohol's and they make amazing homemade lemonade...well it's a little page right out of the South (Austin, TX to be exact).  We need more places like this.    They have a vegan po-boy sandwich with fried avocado that I could eat everyday, it's just that good.  They use the freshest veggies, no really, so fresh that it was probably picked that very day from the Garfield community garden.  That's right, fresh AND local.  I also can't get enough of those delicious collard greens!  I was impressed with the staff because they knew exactly what was vegan (right down to which bread I could eat).  Any time I find a staff educated about ingredients, it's a win.  And anytime I have gone with my non-veg friends they rave about the menu as well, so I think it is safe to say that it is all yummy.  All in all, this place is simply adorable, quaint, fun and delicious.  It is small inside so if you can get in there, I highly recommend it.  The staff is very friendly and attentive which makes for an even better dinning experience.  There are also plenty of seats outside and a to-go window which makes it even easier.  Great place to hang out, meet new people and eat good food!

Dirty.  So dirty.  Hair in the french fries dirty.  Cook sitting on the counter dirty.    Undercoooked hamburger meat, and the server's fingers in my food dirty.  Flies on the lip of the water pitcher dirty.  Somehow these guys think that if you wear gloves you are spared from all contamination.  As if scratching your ass with your gloves on will keep the ass germs from getting in your food.    I've been there before, and have tried to look past all these things, when eating such delicious food, but really, it's not worth it anymore.

Yum! Ordered the welcome burger and fries both were delicious. Seating is outside which was fine. The mixed drinks were really good. Also ordered the beignets & we loved those as well. Service was prompt, & very friendly. Would recommend going now while the weather is nice since seating is outdoors the Summer months may be uncomfortable outside.
So good. Get anything here that comes with/on a biscuit, and you won't be disappointed. The cocktails are great too!

I may have to come back a few more times to see why everyone is going bananas for the place. Our food was awesome but the service was reallllly slow. The young lady taking the orders was extremely polite and friendly but it felt like it took forever to first get up to the window and then to receive our food. I ordered the Big Jim which was a biscuit sandwich that was huge with a friend chicken inside covered in gravy, cheese and bacon. I threw on some Louisiana hot sauce and went at it. I had to eat it with a fork and nice because it was such a good hot mess I couldn't pick it up without ruining the layers. My girl ordered the Little Birdy which was a fried chicken piece topped with cheese and sandwiched in between a biscuit, both came with a couple pieces of watermelon and both were satisfying.  The fact that they close pretty late is awesome and its probably one of the main reasons why I would come back here.

Came here on the suggestion of a cab driver. It was late, and the place I wanted to go to was closed. I had pulled pork mac and cheese, and it was sooo good. I was gonna try the beignets, but I was in the middle of asking the guy behind the counter about them, and he kind of drifted off and forgot to answer me. The inside is very small with about 8 seats and a small air conditioner that won't reach you if you sit by the door. If I ate here again, I'd order to go. 5 stars for the food.

This little gem is tucked away in a quiet neighborhood near downtown Phoenix. We happened to be driving through on the I10 and I am so glad that we stopped. The service was friendly and had some awesome recommendations as it was our first time. Everyone loved their orders, their homemade biscuits were AMAZING. The fried green tomato sandwich on a biscuit, out of this world. It was a quick detour for some of the most memorable flavors on our trip!
Amazing place, cozy and sweet, I was visiting Phoenix and this place and food is stunning. I loved the food.
Great cozy intimate spot. Outdoor setting, feels like your out front your relatives home having brunch.. staff very outgoing and sincere

I loved this spot! I was in town from the midwest and crave Welcome Diner! We indulged in their vegan options. They are def slam packed non stop which is great for them but obviously causes a wait for us. Obviously we ALL wait for this amazing food with no complaints. The staff is friendly, hip and WANTS TO BE THERE! Very chill environment. Huge fan.

Seriously my favorite restaurant in Phoenix! This place is beyond incredible!!  I cannot say enough about the food! The Chipotle Alison donut is my favorite of all time. The chicken is ALWAYS amazing. And the ramen, nothing short of amazing! The staff is super friendly. This place is a true gem.
Love the bumblebee chicken sandwich and the welcome burger was one of the juiciest I have ever tasted. Quick, friendly service. 4 stars because I couldn't find napkins

My husband and I live a couple of blocks away from this charming piece of history. The menu is very limited (hamburgers and hot dogs) but everything that can be gotten from a local grower or manufacturer is. They have a great variety of Southwestern toppings that they will chop and grill freshly for every burger and dog. The fries are freshly cut and delicious. The guys that run the diner are friendly and the prices are reasonable. The hours are from 11 am to 3 pm Monday through Saturday and it is a cash only operation (my only complaints!). The counter inside is tiny and seats less than 10. There are some tables outside, and a take-out window. When we were there, Matt, the owner of Matt's Big Breakfast, was also getting lunch, and it was great to hear how a number of the owners of the downtown small restaurants and shops are long time friends and all support each other. Quaint places with young, hip owners, offering high quality food and goods make us feel positively about living in an often maligned part of town. We'll be back often to support the Welcome Diner.

Laid back atmosphere with outdoor seating next to patio heaters. They sell alcohol and poutine. I got the mac and cheese with jalapeno relish for $10 and some change. I don't think I liked the jalapeno relish much since it had a burnt taste and more of a lemon taste instead of a jalapeno taste. I feel like I was lied to by the lady at the window when I was ordering when it came to what was in the jalapeno relish. The mac and cheese seemed to be missing one of it's key ingredients, cheese. It had some type of cheese sauce instead of actual cheese melted into it. I did not like it at all. It wasn't even heated up, it was straight up cold. I felt like I wasted my money here. Don't think I'll be coming back unless it's to drink some alcohol. I'll give it 2 stars for the outdoor seating and heaters but the food deserves zero stars. My girl wanted to try the poutine but wasn't able to cause they only make gravy with saugage in it and she doesn't eat pork. We both had the mac and cheese and let's just say her review would have been harsher than mine. Go somewhere else if you're hungry.

Welcome Diner is a good place to go when the weather is nice and you've got lots of time on your hands. It's in kind of a strange neighborhood (you may see stray dogs running around) but the outside dining area is welcoming and cute. I don't like coming in here any kind of inclement weather because pretty much all of the seating is outside, which is a bummer at night or during the summer. Also, because the kitchen is so small and Welcome Diner is so popular, you may end up waiting 40 minutes for your food.  But....what saves Welcome Diner for me is the food. I love the fried chicken and the sausage biscuits and gravy. The sandwiches are also excellent! The orange juice is fresh-squeezed and refreshing, but the lemonade is on the bitter side and leaves something to be desired. I'd recommend the food at Welcome Diner to anyone, but the atmosphere isn't always a crowd-pleaser. I would love to see them in a brick and mortar, full-service restaurant! Maybe someday.

Super cute place, mostly outdoor seating, really quality, tasty food - awesome mac-n-chz especially. Also had Pulled pork biscuit sandwich and we had the whitefish po'boy.  All delish and look foward to trying the burgers and fries....  Just wished it was a teeny bit less expensive on certain things. Otherwise yummy and would definately recommend

Loved. Super duper friendly service. The bumble bee was delicious and filling. Chicken was juicy and flavorful. They made me a margarita even though not on the menu. The boyfriend was very pleased they played the pixies. Casual, neighborhood vibe.
Best spot for late night grub, cool ambiance, and damn good food. Highly recommend when in downtown Phx!!!

This is a place I check out most First Fridays. I like that it's open late, so after walking around and working up an appetite, it's great to find a place with great food. Seating is outdoors. The food itself is awesome. I usually get a chicken biscuit. The biscuit is great and so was the chicken. They have gravy fries (putain), but I would get those only if you have someone to split them with.

My husband and I stopped in this restaurant this evening. The looks of the place was quaint and nothing like we had expected. It was better! It's the smallest diner I have ever been to,yet pleasant and clean. Even the outside tables and chairs were very clean. The young man who waited on us was friendly and helpful, and very cute, looks a bit like John Mayer. Anyway...the food is outstanding! I had a burger with mushrooms, cooked to my order. Came with the right amount of fries. The burger was delicious and plenty. My husband had the chicken sandwich, never had one so good. And for you single gals out there, the cook was as hot as the grill!  The cole slaw was different but very good. My husband ordered coffee and apple pie,the coffee was made fresh. The pie was a huge slice and worth trying..... YUMMO! The staff there was friendly,service was great. Welcome Diner is a must try.

Went here for first time Feb 2016 and had the grilled cheese, green tomato sammie, and fries. All were delicious! The sourdough bread was exceptional. Looking forward to trying more dishes. We will definitely be back. Charming neighborhood eatery with friendly staff.

I have no idea how such a tiny place is able to churn out such an enormous amount of quality food.  The patio is large and eclectic with an array of mismatching tables, chairs, and lights. It's hard not to immediately feel at home here. Food has been exceptional on every visit, my favorite item being the fried green tomato sandwich. Cocktails have also been superb. It's a good bet that whatever you decide on will be both surprising and just what you were hoping for.  My husband and I had our wedding dinner at Welcome Diner and it was absolutely perfect. Before friends arrived I warned the staff that there was a sizable group coming by and if we were in the way or too loud to please let me know and I'd deal with it. The staff's response was, "That's just the vibe here. You're fine." They handled the crowd that night so well, and with such great and friendly energy.

I will start out by saying the food was good. The drinks and the rest of the experience with the staff and the manager was enough for me to got to jail if I didn't have enough control not to hit them.  The old fashion was one of the worst I've ever had. I took the drink back to the bar, the bartender ask me what was wrong? I told him a old fashion shouldn't be red, to much bitters and to many mashed up cherries. He I formed me that's how he makes them. Ok great but it tased awful, he did pour me a straight bourbon, that wasn't to hard to make. At this point I was annoyed. Then the waiter told us our outside drinks could be inside the white fence area, because it was a health code violation I was Irritating due to the limited selection of coke, products.  Was going to leave at this point asked for boxes to take food home at this point. Decided to Take the drinks to the car. Ten minutes later a cat jumps on to the table. I told the waiter that it happened his smart ass remark was he didn't see it. This was the point I lost it, went in ask for the manager. The manager was standing right there, but walked outside as I demanded to see him another employee went and got him. I met him outside and the waiter. At this point I was really pissed off and lost my temper. They told me that can't control the yard, but I have to remove my drink that's controlling the yard but the cat that jumps on to my dinner table isn't their problem. I'm a little confused about that. If it was a rat or a mouse or other bugs it be their problem to control.   I will be calling the health department on Monday and hopefully the owner or real manger of this restaurant will respond so we can talk about how unprofessional their staff was. I admit I lost my temper, but the waiter reply to the cat being on the table after talking to me about health code violation pissed me off.    Real irritating after sending $72.00 on a decent meal to have a bad experience with the staff.

Legit burger! I had paradise valley burger earlier in the day and the burger here was better in my opinion. I had the peanut butter burger with bacon and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Much better value compared to PVB. I also had a biscuit with honey and it was delicious also. Great place, really enjoyed the overall experience. Wish they were open for lunch too.
This is one if my new favorite places. Great little patio/outdoor area. Small menu of great dinner food done well. Cool cocktails. Near neighborhood.
Food so good!  Staff so good!  Neat little old trailer and patio so GOOD!!
fun place--l wish they served lunch when the weather is cool--great fries

Fun local place to hang out and grab a bite when it's a reasonable temperature outside. My bumblebee was excellent. They definitely have the fried chicken and biscuits down.  My friends' three burgers were all overcooked to well-done without the any hint of pink. They're not burger snobs like I am and had no complaints but i probably would have. I also felt the drinks were weak or watered down for $10 a pop. I'll probably be back to try some other food, but it wasn't a home-run as I had hoped.

This review is for a visit back in August, we stopped in for dinner before a D'backs game.  I had the fish po'boy which was so good and eclipsed only by the roasted brussels sprouts.  My dad really enjoyed the Welcome Burger with fries and a PBR.  A cold gin and tonic and an outside seat for people watching under the misters.  Don't miss this great little find in Phoenix!

This place is the best!! A favorite neighborhood go to with a good happy hour! Their biscuits are made in house and the chicken is always fried perfectly! We got the little birdy (chicken, cheese, biscuit) simple and delicious! They use country gravy on their poutine which is different but still tasty. We also got the champion burger. The meat was cooked perfect and bacon jam is one of the toppings. Where has this been all my life?! On happy hour whiskey sours are only 4$ and its one of the best around.  They are also open late and have happy hour all day on Tuesdays. It's a hidden gem that everyone should know about!

Wow .... wow... We moved to the Garfield Neighborhood about a month ago and have been putting off going here, first because I was never sure when it was open and next because it looked incredibly small and over crowded every time I drove by. Turns out they're open fairly normal hours and the patio is pretty big..... my fault.   My wife and I both ordered burgers I just got the normal welcome burger (I think that's the name) and my wife got a peanut butter topped burger. The food got to us fast and my burger was the best I'm had in months! my only real complaint is that I didn't order the same burger as my wife because her burger was way better than mine! oh and also if you get fries you get about 10 ... A really tasty 10 but not enough or maybe it was an illusion and they just need smaller plates.   I'll be going back soon for burgers and probably to try a few other menu items as well!

I love this place. What a neat little local gem in the Garfield Historic District.  The food is delicious and the drinks are made with love and real juices. This is my favorite brunch spot downtown, and any day this is the best place to eat latenight. They'll give you the best comfort food you could possibly need, and serve your friend the best lovingly-created vegan food simultaneously.  The staff is amazing and their product is flawless, quality , and local. Love love love!!!

When my wife suggested going to a diner for dinner, my mind immediately went to comfort food. You know, those culinary staples that we all need in good times and bad. Needless to say, I was looking forward to it.  When we arrived at Welcome Diner, my first observation was the location. A somewhat rundown neighborhood undergoing changes of gentrification. The diner itself sits on the corner directly across from what looked like an old market that had been turned into a cafe/bar. Overall, a very intriguing location within a very positive and vibrant community.   You don't order your food at Welcome Diner like you would at your normal greasy spoon. There isn't the smell of fried potatoes and stale coffee or a waitress with big Texas hair brining you biscuits and gravy. You actually order your food from a small window in front of the diner. Once you order, you can sit inside if there is room or sit outside. The weather last night was really nice. Not hell hot, so we sat outside. FYI, finding seating outside can be a little hairy. There are several tables and some counter type seating, but all of the outside seating is first come, first serve.  The menu is simple, but take comfort food to a whole new level. To give you an example, when I think about a diner, I think about meatloaf. So I ordered Welcome's version. A Chorizo Meatloaf covered in a Chipotle and white wine cream sauce, picked vegetables, and Brahbant potatoes. Very innovative in my book. When you cut into the meatloaf you get an incredible burst of flavor with the sauce and pickled veg. The potatoes added the salty flavor to the sweetness of the pickled veg. My wife ordered the Koko, which was a sandwich consisting of a pieces fried chicken, covered in Chipotle ranch dressing topped with tomato and arugula. Then all of the aforementioned is stuff between a sliced biscuit. I only sampled the chicken, but it was full of flavor an tender. My daughter ordered the bacon Mac N' Cheese. She at a little more than half of it, which told me it was off the charts. I tried it and loved it. The bacon in the Mac N' Cheese wasn't just your average, tiny bacon bits. It was actual small pieces of bacon. As a side, we ordered the roasted Brussels sprouts. they weren't roasted as much as I do them at home, but they were still good. I also ordered a Manhattan off of their cocktail menu.  No complaints on the service or wait staff. Everyone we interacted with was very friendly. Especially the gentleman who took our order at the window. He wasn't rushing people and chatting with them a bit. Basically, making you feel.....Welcome. Parking was easy for us to find. In fact, we got a spot right in front of the diner itself. I noticed a lot of people were Ubering to the diner as well.  If I'm ever in the Phoenix area again, I'm definitely going back to the Welcome Diner.

I think this place is a must for those who love the phx food scene. They have a small indoor seating which is within a small trailer so preferably sit outside. The popular menu item here is called the big Jim and it's definitely worth it. A fried chicken breast sandwiches between two big biscuits with bacon and cheese. Then it's smothered with gravy that's oh so good. I also recommend getting some French fries, Mac and cheese and maybe even a drink. Great thing also about this place is that it opens late! So for those to come out of LUXX and want to turn down, this place is a less than a mile away.

This late night diner has all the perfect comfort food that you can dream of.  From biscuits and gravy to jambalaya, the food is fantastic, and I always get a few laughs from the staff. Definitely a classic and local favorite of downtown. The chicken is on point as-well.

What a great little find. A little oasis in the middle of a foreboding neighborhood. Have been a few times (once twice in the same day) and not yet disappointed. Except, once when i came on a monday and they were closed.

I told my hubby we absolutely had to stop by welcome diner during our trek to Phoenix.   From downtown we took a short lightrail ride (because he doesn't like to walk recreationally) then ironically still had to walk for what appeared to be forever through the sketchy part of town -- no we didn't take the art district route.  The diner literally is a mobile kitchen. Bigger than a food truck, I mean enough to situate a counter, a line of barstools and the cooking area. The guys on board are super friendly, accommodating and truly love the contribution they've made to the community.  Yes this little kitchen serves cocktails and beer.  We ordered the acclaimed big Jim, two of them, hash browns and beignets.   Our big Jims were delicious. Extremely hearty with extra gravy. Unfortunately, however, without the gravy, the biscuit would be just thirst inducingly dry.  I suppose that would be one way to get you to drink more!    Again loved the gravy. They even gave me a ramikin of their mushroom gravy cause they felt I had to try it..also quite delicious.   The hash browns and beignets were alright but didn't contribute to this diner's stars.  We were impressed with our main entrees and by the guys who run this little miracle on wheels.

This is one of the best restaurants in Phoenix, and you literally get to eat outside at a picnic table.  I came here due to extrinsic circumstances, and would not have ordinarily tried it based on it's location/outward appearance; but, after eating here, I realize I would have been a fool to avoid it.  This is a must eat restaurant!

Cool diner in the middle of my changing neighborhood. Lots of wild conversations , no space inside and the kitchen is Right in ur face! My friend Olivia was drinkin something sweet lol, and I'm not sure what it was called but good mix! Enjoyed the bumble bee chicken sandwich , dijon mustard and honey on top of the bread was bomb!  I didn't sit outside but it looked nice , but I did dig the inside and enjoyed myself. This place is hipsterific and I'm fine with that, come here for a different taste of Phx...  4 STARS

Lots of vegan and vegetarian options. The fried green tomato sandwich was tasty but very messy, and made the bread quite soggy. The chess pie was delicious. The outdoor space was fun to hang out in after hours. Friendly staff.

Welcome Diner has made me rethink fries with toppings. Someone (chef) tell me the secret of layering your already tasty fries with savory pork and somehow keeping the fries crispy underneath?! It's one of life's greatest mysteries but I am okay with it. Can't wait to return for a homemade whiskey sour- the mix is tangy and tart and just plain yummy.
I wish I could pack this place up and take it back to Lawrence with me!! Love it. -Maisie. Cousin of Joe from Jayhawk Country.

Such a cute place! Perfect hang out spot with friends they close at 2am! Even cute for a first date! Not many vegetarian/vegan options though. I loved the feeling of being at home, the customer service was excellent they even gave us a little down town history! Will deff go back! Thank you welcome dinner!

Well this was a nice surprise. Great food, awesome service, area slightly sketchy, and I definitely wish there was more good seating.   You walk up to order at the little window,  sit down,  and they'll bring your meal out. Takes a good 15+ minutes to make your food , so a nice wait.   The poutine uses cream gravy instead of brown.  Different,  but still good.  The pork bbq fries were great. The pulled pork was heated up on the griddle which gave it a nice crisp. Tasty too!  The beignets were the star of the night. Wow! Outstanding taste and quality.  Make sure to get those.  Good place, try it out!!

The Welcome Diner is a welcome experience. Modern meets the past in this old school diner setting with an infusion of handcrafted mixed drinks using unusual ingredients (Creosote, anyone?) and delicious food. My friend and I grabbed two appetizers, including pulled pork french fries (they had a Jackfruit fries option!) and Octopus Masa Balls. Wow! They were kind of like hush puppies, and we giggled a lot about the name. I forget the name of my drink but it was like a ice smoothie with absinthe in it and was so yummy. I had a Big Jim burger on a biscuit smothered in gravy with cheese for $11. Huge! And different, and tasty! I'd love to come back and see how they progress and if the menu changes over time, which the waitress said it probably would.
Great atmosphere to be in, especially when it's late and you're wanting to eat a nice meal! I always get the macaroni with bacon and its so delicious?  :) Wonderful people here!

What a fun place to have chicken and biscuits. Very small with a larger outdoor area. If you have a hankering for fried chicken this is the place.   The biscuits were amazing. Light with substance. A joy to eat. I wanted more  The fried chicken was not greasy and super moist.

So I was downtown today doing some charity work with friends. One of them mentioned that we had to try out "Welcome Diner". So we did. OMG!!! Found my new favorite Burger spot. Everything was amazing. Literally the BEST fries I've ever had. Plus they have a full bar and ice cold beer. I highly recommend it and will be back soon. Manager Zach is really nice too!
Great little funky place.  Unique food done very well.  Inexpensive place to chill out open late.

I just love everything about this place. The location, the outside seating, the vibe, the food ... everything.  The kitchen is very small. This vintage diner car was meant for one cook. So the two guys in there really have to hustle and work around each other. The food is top quality as well. My boyfriend and I split a PB&B Burger and the Bumblebee chicken sandwich on a biscuit. The chicken was probably my favorite, but it was impossible to eat like a lady. It's stacked so high that in order to get some in your mouth, you have to get some on your face. I gave up and just started stabbing at it with my fork.   The best part of Welcome Diner is the atmosphere: twinkling lights, picnic style seating, and friendly staff. I'm not sure who was working this last Saturday night, but he was so friendly and knowledgeable. We had a good little conversation about the history of the diner car.   This would be a great date place ... if that's something you're looking for. This is also a good place for a group of around 6 friends to take over a picnic table.

I will say I was a little surprised to drive up to this place and see it is in a neighborhood on the corner as if it was previously someone's house (pretty sure it may have been). As for seating there are two options either outside on their "patio" (felt like someones front yard with chairs) or inside which gave you more of an old school dining car feel. I ordered there PB + B burger and my husband had their shrimp Po'boy special. I had heard eating Peanut butter on your burger was good so of course I had to give it a try. I must say it was a bit odd but very good, the burger was very juicy and flavorful, the bacon and cheese gave it that salty taste that went great along side the crunchy peanut butter. I would say it probably isn't for everyone and fair warning it is very heavy on the stomach... about half way through it just hits you and realize just how full you are lol. My husband's Shrimp Po'Boy was very good, the bread was super fresh and the tomato base spread gave it amazing flavor, I would say it was more of a "Prawn" Po'boy because the shrimp were so big. Overall the food was very good, I am a bit skeptical about the outdoor seating it was just a little too weird for me, I would definitely go back but would prefer to sit inside if there is room. I hope they continue to do well and maybe they'll be able to expand.

One of my favorite places in Phoenix, Welcome Diner offers a modern twist on comfort foods like chicken and biscuits, fries, etc.  Their servings were very generous and our food came out pretty quickly -especially considering we visited on a Friday night during prime dinner hours.   I particularly love that they offer veggie-friendly options.. their bbq jackfruit burgers and fries are amazing!! It can be hard to find restaurants that accommodate vegetarians, which makes this place even more special.  Just a heads up tho, the majority of seating here is outdoors. Aka. be prepared during the winter months for the cold/ during the summer months for the heat.. I think there are like 5 seats inside near the kitchen, but otherwise everything else is picnic benches or tables :) I'll definitely be back here once it's a little warmer again outside!

Decided to try this place out after reading the review here. My Wife and I are glad we did.   This place was sooo good. A true diamond in the rough.   The food was perfect. My Wife had the welcome burger and fries. It came out cook exactly the way she asked. I tried the big jim and the cannibal fries. I was only able to eat mine with a fork and knife. It hit the spot. The fires we excellent!!.   We each had a drink with our meal, they did not disappoint either.   I would eat here all the time if I lived closer, so maybe that is a good thing. I would weight about 500lbs.   If you are even remotely close, check this place out!!!
Delish, but overpriced for a burger joint.

What a great local spot! Off the beaten path amongst single family homes you would most likely not find if you didn't search it out. It's a mostly outdoor venue so in the Arizona summers, beware. There is a small seating area inside, about 7 seats.  My favorite food option is the bumblebee!! Fried chicken with honey smack dab in the middle of two yummy biscuits. Yum!!  I haven't tried a drink here yet but hear they are delicious! That's next on the list.
Delicious grub. Highly recommended. The Big Jim lives up to the hype. And they sell beer too. Just a half mile away. Good for Cardinal's game day.

I'm TORN. Between writing this review for the staff an owners of welcome and the potential influx of customers. This diner has been an very meaningful and influential part of my Arizona life. From meeting some of my best friends to my roommate that allowed me to move just two blocks away from this amazing place. To late night burger runs to a disappointed Monday bike ride, I've loved it all. If I had my Monday back for every welcome burger I've had I might actually be able to afford a car but I regret nothing. I feel for the staff that deals with the question of alterations on their already perfect menu. (Written while listening to the dumbest of request)   I may move onto other states of employment and residency but I hope to forever return to a place that has meant so much to me.

I heard a lot of great things about this place and was super excited to check it out. I ordered the Bumblebee (fried chicken, biscuit, honey, mustard) and my husband ordered the  PB&B burger (burger with peanut butter and bacon).  My dish came with a few pieces of sweet watermelon and his came with a side of slaw. We first experienced a peanut butter burger at rehab where they also add grape jelly and sriracha and my husband has been on a PB burger roll ever since. He thought his burger was very tasty and ate his whole plate. I liked my biscuit dish but I think I was expecting something a little more....substantial? The chicken was really great and moist but it felt like there was something missing. I think I was expecting it to be slathered in honey/sauces but it was certainly worth the price ($8.50). I'd definitely come again but I think I'll try another dish next time.
Great dive in the middle of downtown. Great food and drinks are strong. One of the best grilled cheese sandwiches I have ever had. Very good!

I've never had anything I didn't love here but tonight was cold and the patio was still packed. My friend and I shared a Hot Toddy and, by recommendation from the gentleman in the window, mac n cheese with chorizo. I would've gone with fried chicken but he said chorizo was his preference. It was delicious. The Toddy and macaroni was perfect comfort food on a cold night. This is only one experience. I've brought everyone from friends, dates, and clients to my mom, brother and sisters all separately. Let's just say I love this place and I love introducing new people to it. Most people go for the Big Jim fried chicken sandwich and I won't wrong them for it but you have to try their Po Boy, poutines, burgers and jackfruit dishes. You get lucky if you can find room at the counter but the patio is very comfortable and the service outside is exceptional and with a smile. Tell your friends!

The 'No way Jose' burger was one of the best burgers I have had. I would say in the list of top 5 burgers in my life. When I ordered medium rare they explained "our medium rare is warm to the touch in the middle, mostly red on the inside and a little bloody". That's exactly how it came out and it tasted amazing.

Love, love, love Welcome Diner. Solid food and solid service make this a favorite. Just had the PB&B burger with real deal THICK cut bacon, bread and butter pickles and my favorite chunky peanut butter. Cooked to perfection and delivered promptly, it went down quick with an ice cold PBR. Before dinner I had their version of Sazerac, made with a rye whiskey in lieu of cognac. Delish. Probably my new favorite summer whiskey drink! Also to die for is the bumblebee, imagine an amazing chicken sandwich on a top notch biscuit drizzled with honey. Yum! I'm full as I write this waiting on beignets that were comped because our side of fries didn't make it out, but I could eat a bumblebee because it's that good. So great food, great drinks and a great al fresco dining experience make Welcome Diner one of my favorite spots in Phoenix. If you come at night sit at the big round table on the 10th street side for great views of downtown.

I love the Welcome Diner. It's my favorite spot for late night eats in Phoenix (opens till 2am). It's such a cool concept and they serve up some pretty good-sized portions of food. Welcome Diner operates out of a Valentine Diner (a mobile pop-up restaurant from the 40's) and is located in the historic Garfield neighborhood (they have a second location in Tucson). They have both outdoor and limited indoor seating and serve up Southern-inspired American dishes made from scratch. You'll find huge buttermilk biscuit sandwiches, burgers, po' boy sandwiches, fried chicken and jambalaya on their menu along with a variety of delicious cocktails to choose from. In fact, Connor Mansager of the Welcome Diner was recently declared the 2017 Arizona Star Bartender at the Devour Phoenix Bartending Competition a couple weeks ago. I pulled a late nighter here with some buddies and we tore up a Big Jim (fried chicken, gravy, bacon and an egg on a biscuit), No Way Jose (a burger with jalapeno relish, smoked Gouda and chipotle ranch) and the Carol (braised pork and BBQ sauce on a biscuit). Another favorite of mine is the Peanut Butter burger. Our food definitely hit the spot after a fun night of boozing. Btw... share a side of fries with someone as they are pretty generous with their portions. I love the throwback ambiance of this place to old school diners of the past. My only knock is we had some smokers next to us as we ate our food on the patio. But overall a great experience as always and the staff is usually pretty friendly.

After a big night during First Friday, tired and slightly hungover, I needed some comfort food.  Outside of the Five & Diner franchise, I hadn't been to anything resembling an authentic diner in the Phoenix area.  Ever.  So what a surprise to find an old diner transplanted from back east into the downtown Phoenix area.  It's a little on the fringes as the immediate neighborhood is a little sketchy, but we were going for a late breakfast on a Saturday so I didn't worry too much about my car.  The diner itself truly is a timewarp.  The interior is a simple 9 stool diner with a cooking area just as tiny.  You can't help but converse with the waitress and the cooking staff since they're basically right in front of your face.  If you're looking for more room (and want to keep an eye on your ride), there's picnic tables with umbrellas outside.  We got here around 11am so my girlfriend and I didn't feel too self conscious ordering drinks.  I got the mimosa while she got the bloody mary.  I'm not sure what they put in those drinks, but they had some kick!  They weren't overtly alcoholic, but just spicier than other mimosas or bloody marys I've had.  As for the food, I came here for one thing.  A biscuit sandwich.  More specifically, the Big Jim.  Fried chicken, country gravy, bacon, and cheddar on a homemade biscuit.  Unreal.  The biscuit was flaky, buttery heaven.  The batter on the fried chicken was delicious and the gravy wonderfully hearty.  Easily the best biscuit sandwich I've had in the Phoenix area.  My girlfriend got the Andouille Scramble which was basically an omelette with andouille sausage, peppers and onions with a side of potatoes.  She saw how much I loved my biscuit so she added a biscuit with honey to her order and was equally impressed.  We so wanted to save room for the beignets, but we were stuffed.  Total for the two drinks, two entrees, the add-on biscuit, and tip came to about $40.  Had we done non-alcoholic drinks it would've been a little under $30.  Their ingredients are locally sourced so you pay a little bit of a premium for that.  But considering the quality of the food and the unique experience, it was money well spent.  Whatever you do, find a way somehow to include a biscuit in your meal here.
Food was on point. Only a half dozen seats inside,  but plenty of seating outside! The food is creative and delicious.

Went after seeing Taruk at the Talking Stick Resort Arena (America West/US Airways Arena).  Finally in the area while they're open!  Woohoo!  Got there and checked out the menu - interesting assortment of foods.  Everybody's happy!  Got our order in and sat back down...the rain started to move from a drizzle to steady...no cover outside (just shade cloth) and all 9 of the inside seats were taken.  Switched our order to takeout and sent everyone to the car.  Got the order and headed home.  Almost none of the fries survived the drive (we were hungry, and they were really tasty!)  I ordered the Bumblebee - that's a southern fried chicken breast (boneless) biscuit sandwich.  It had dijon mustard, pickles, and honey...not really my flavor profile - not sure if it was the mustard or the pickles, but just missed by a bit for my taste (biscuit was great, chicken was very good).  Everybody enjoyed their orders, and we finished up with beignets - great way to finish off!!!

Great spot. I would def recommend this spot for comfort food. The fried chicken sandwich is not to be missed & the fries are amazing! Just ask for extra crispy. Can't wait to go back & try a burger they looked amazing!!!!

Right in downtown phoenix, a semi small Diner turned outside patio dining southern foodie haven.. Did someone say biscuits and gravy with fried chicken? How about you add some bacon too and then top it off with some beignets? Legit fried chicken and the biscuits are yummy. Great friendly service behind the small counter where you can see the cooking and the bartending happening. Or walk up outside and order and find your own table. Gotta try the Big Jim or the Bumblebee. Definitely will be back to try the Po'Boys and the poutine fries. Love that they are right down the road from us and I can go satisfy my southern cravings.   Beignets are 3 to an order and not Cafe DuMonde but the honey drizzle s fantastic! They have a liquor license and the drinks were pouring...street parking or across the street, there is a lot.

I adore Welcome Diner. There's so much to love about this restaurant. I absolutely adore the outdoor seating, especially during the cooler months in Arizona, with the gorgeous overhead lights. The service is always excellent; everyone that works here genuinely looks like they enjoy their job. Brace yourselves for long lines, and a long wait for your food. Don't worry, the food is worth the wait!   My favorite items on the menu are Bumblebee and Koko. I love the taste of salty and sweet together; if you are the same way then you would certainly enjoy Bumblebee. The delicious crispy chicken pairs well with the honey. I am not usually a fan of biscuits but they do it so well at Welcome Diner. Koko is also my favorite. This is what I order when I prefer something less tasty but equally as good as Bumblebee. I always pair my sandwiches with their delicious french fries, paired with their (garlic?) sauce. My boyfriend always get their burger (No Way Jose) and he loves it. Welcome Diner is not just perfect for brunch or dinner. It is the perfect place to just hang out and have a drink with friends.

Food was great. Nice chill location, unpretentious with food and alcohol, I'm there! It was around midnight that we decided to go and plus we've always wanted to try this place. I heard it gets really busy on the weekends so thurs was the perfect time to try it out. It's strange how the diner sits in the middle of a quiet neighborhood but whatever, I'm here for the food. We got the poutine fries, fried chicken biscuit sandwich, a side salad, and beignets to top it off. Everything was so delicious even down to the salad.  I would definitely come here again. The beignets are a little more dense than the ones in New Orleans and I've never had it with honey before but nonetheless it was still pretty yummy.

First time at Welcome Diner. Really good looking menu but the execution really failed.   I arrived at 7:30 on a Friday night with my daughter and her husband. We were 15th in line yet didn't get a table for an hour. With one window taking all of the orders, it was painfully slow.   Our food didn't arrive for another 40 minutes. Yes, an hour and forty total. Brutal. I ordered a burger with poutine fries as a side, along with water. My daughter got the fried green tomato sandwich and water while her husband got the jambalaya and a coke.  After ordering you have to 'fight' for a table, which are few. We sat with two other couples at the family style seating.   My burger was good but the fries were awful. I'd never had poutine before but it was cold. I grabbed my first fry and got a mass of 15 fries welded together. Poorly done. The fried green tomato sandwich was another fail, as the toast was thick, hard and cold. She ended up eating it open faced. The jambalaya was okay.   Service was non-existent so we were ignored.   I may try Welcome Diner again, based on the clever menu but I am hesitant.

I got a burger here and it was absolutely amazing. So good that I just had to return a week later to try the other burger on the menu. I also got a few bites of the fried chicken biscuit, the mac and cheese, and the gumbo. All very good (but the burger totally wins).

WOW!!   What an amazing location and staff! We came here on a Tuesday night for our first time and couldn't believe how rad and friendly the staff were.   There food was delicious and super affordable! We got the Big Jim with the chipotle ranch and it was to die for.   This place deserves more than 5 stars!

This quaint diner is set in downtown Phoenix in a residential area. They do not have much for children, thus may not be the best place for family with toddlers. Because it's outside seating, it's best to go in the evening when weather is cooler. I had the no way Jose burger  which was very tasty, and my 11 yr old had the Mac&cheese; she loves it! They cool to order so you may have to wait awhile before your food is served. We waited about 25mins. I will definitely go back again and try some of their biscuits and gravy dishes.

I've been a vegetarian for just over 3 years now and the jackfruit poboy was the best "meat substitute" meal I've ever had. I appreciated all the options I had too. They are willing to sub jackfruit for any of the non-vegetarian dishes. On top of that, the service was great even with it being full for happy hour. We will be back!

I was right, coming back more has made this place grow on me. The hurricanes are so much better than they were before and the food is amazing. The staff is all great and I've become friends with several of them.   Try the jackfruit fries, O.M.G.
This place is great. Get the Big Jim, it is outstanding. The staff are so laid back and nice.

Update:   After reading the talk thread on yelp about the welcome diner I am so happy that they are not closing!  Turns out they decided not to and now are going to open a second one in the not too distant future.  I am so sad that I came here on the last day that this little diner will be open.  I was introduced to this place by a friend of mine who is a regular patron.  It was a nice Saturday afternoon so we ate outside and I think the little diner (with 8 seats) was full.  I had a single patty cheeseburger and the favorite and a coke.  The favorite is fresh cut fries with peppers, onions and a few other things that made this a delicious side dish.  It was all soooo good... I am glad I had the opportunity to try it.
This place has amazing food.  I had the fish and it was so good.  Spicy!   The drinks are really good too.  Check out the Ginger beer.   Come for happy hour and enjoy

Welcome Diner has become one of my Phoenix favorites.   It's hard to tell which stands out the most, their amazing food preparations or their welcoming staff.   1st patronage: we were able to sit inside the tiny trailer and the guys who were working that day were awesome. Great customer service, made us feel known and welcomed! That day I enjoyed the Welcome Burger with no regrets! Husband got the Big Jim & was very satisfied!   2nd patronage: I popped by for an iced coffee (they serve Lux brew) , and the gal working (can't remember her name now, but she's got blue hair ;) was super friendly! She even hooked me up with a refill for the price of free, I was like wow, these folks are nice :)  3rd patronage: we weren't feeling meat, so we tried the Vegan Po' Boy...was surprised at what a delicious sandwich it was, nothing poor about it!   Their fries are the best around. Their coleslaw is distinct. Their service is appreciated. I'm looking forward to enjoying more meals here.   I'm busy and really don't have time to write reviews, but I'll type one up for a local business I want to support! They also use all local AZ grown ingredients folks.   Don't be intimidated by the humble surroundings from the outdoor seating area. It's comfortable and unpretentious, a sweet little spot to enjoy some real good food.

Good service and yummy food. I had the PB&B burger and my boyfriend had the No Way Jose burger. Both were good and we both enjoyed the fries. We plan to eat there regularly now! I do recommend to get there early or prepare to stand in line and wait by the fence for an available table.
