Welcome Diner was a welcome distraction in an otherwise very busy day. We had heard it was one of the best places to eat in Phoenix, and I can see why. Delicious, home style, southern food.   I ordered the bumblebee chicken biscuit sandwich. It was a little sweet for my taste, but that's understandable as honey is the star ingredient, but after some hot sauce all the flavors balanced out nicely.    My wife ordered the fried green tomato sandwich and she loved it. We also ordered poutine fries--I loved the gravy--and beignets for dessert.   Now I'm a little picky about my beignets, as I moved from Houston and visited NOLA often,  and these don't match up to Cafe Du Monde or other NOLA spots, but they were still finger licking good. Literally, the woman next to me was scraping the last of the honey out of her beignet bowl with her fingers and licking it off. And I could sympathize. I didn't want my meal to end after my last bite either.   The restaurant is very small. A handful of indoor seats and a small outdoor, community picnic style eating area. It took about fourty minutes for us to get our meal after we ordered, and that was with only 2 people in front of us at the order window. This felt like ages, but I forgot about all that when I took the first bite of my biscuit. We will be back. If you haven't been here yet, just go, so worth it!  Edit 2/26/16 Take out is definitely the way to do it!! Placed our order on the phone and was able to pick it up about 20 minutes later on a Friday night!!  The Champion Burger- Mmm, This is a tasty burger (Samuel L. Jackson Pulp Fiction voice).  If you're in the mood for a hamburger just order this!  You can't go wrong with The Champion Burger, it's a winner!!  The Mac & Cheese was yummy, adding Tomato Confit and Jalapeo Relish made it extravagant!

Grew up in Canada and Poutine was a staple. This was different with southern gravy instead of brown gravy, but it works especially on their fries. Wed. has a happy hour featuring those same fries with pulled pork and a very special Cole slaw. Add a burger and a beer and you've got more than enough for two for dinner at under $25. This is serious food, done by m who really care about doing it right.

For those that haven't heard, Payton Curry has taken over Welcome Diner April through May on Sun, Mon, Tues, and First Fridays. Get there... now. Payton is known for pushing limits and incorporating fresh, local ingredients. The menu will likely change every week, if not every night, so I'm not sure if my recap will help all that much, but here goes.  The neighborhood is sketchy, the place is tiny, and the accommodations are "rustic", so if you're all into the Scottsdale scene or flashing your dough, don't bother. That being said, Shantal mentioned that being there made her feel like she was camping every night, and I have to admit the evening had a vacation feel to it... National Lampoon's style!  You can instantly tell that Payton is having a blast and it shows on his face and in the food. We were seated on a collection of old dining chairs at a makeshift table of 2x8s and construction horses in the middle of the front yard, with a candle to light our way... I knew it was going to be a sweet evening!  We started with the burrata that was lightly seasoned with truffle oil and cracked pepper. Unfortunately a lot of people are adding burrata to their menus and they have no idea that this fresh, creamy, delicate version is how it's truly meant to be. It was served with slices of toast that I expected to be the brick-hard version to which I've become accustomed. Imagine my surprise as I bit into a spongy, buttery slice of bread with just a crunch of the crust! Delicious.  The porcini foie gras terrine will scare those faint of heart, but it's amazing and the pear butter adds this velvety, sweet flavor that just makes it unforgettable. I wasn't a fan of the pate', but it was a combination of pickle, horseradish, and mustard flavors with chunks in the loaf... all things I can personally only handle in moderation individually and generally dislike, so it was exactly as described. The mains arrived and the Sonoma lamb sugo proved to be an interesting choice. It's not something you would eat on a regular basis, but I'm so glad I got to try it. The shreds of lamb meat were piled on top of a bowl of hearty fettuccine with perfectly cooked chickpeas and dollops of cream that muted any gaminess of the meat. Then you would get a bite of golden raisin to kick in a touch of sweetness; pretty cool combination of flavors and textures without being over the top.  Perhaps the biggest surprise of the night was the bowl of Bolognese that was planted in front of us, it blew me away and I have no idea why!! Payton, what's your secret with something so simple? Dessert followed with apple pie that could've been much tastier if it were warmed with a scoop of ice cream, but all was rescued with a huge chunk of bread pudding that puts my mother's recipe to shame (and it was served warmed with a scoop of ice cream :).   All in all, we had a wonderful night with fabulous food and fun friends and we didn't want the night to end. If you want a hint of adventure, get to Welcome Diner before the end of May... seriously... National Lampoon's style.  ps: It's BYOB!

This place is AWESOME. Seriously a gem in the area. I was taken here last night and returned tonight because it was a no brainier. This is the perfect spot for a late date night. Great food and awesome drinks. I am a huge fan of the ginger beer(added it to a old fashion). They have a really awesome staff that really work hard. They have great customer service skills and seem to really like working there. All around this is a great business and I will be back many more times in the future.

My husband and I have driven past this place many a night on our way home from King's Convenience and it was always so full, we never thought to park the car and stroll on in. Last Friday night we got lucky and got a seat inside - yay! After enjoying the food from Welcome Chicken and Donuts on Broadway oh so much, I knew Welcome Diner wasn't going to disappoint. Our server, Taylor, was so enthusiastic and knowledgeable about every dish and all of its ingredients - it's such a joy to see someone take pride in their work and I haven't even gotten to the food yet. We started off with the roasted brussell sprouts - yummy charred goodness plus it was a vegetable which buffered the other stuff I'm about to mention .... We both got chicken and biscuit masterpieces - The Bumblebee for me with its delicious pickles and honey mustard - all scratch made. My husband got the Big Jim - all I can say is "wow" - everything you could ever want in your life from the chicken, the bacon, the biscuit and the gravy. Oh, and did I mention their gorgeous, craft cocktails? They have those too. Now on to dessert - chocolate chunk. pecan. sea salt. pie - and believe me you get gorgeous chunks of everything in every bite! Their coffee is pretty darn fantastic too - from Piexoto in Chandler.  All in all, a damn perfect experience.

A unique spot with great food!  I had heard good things about Welcome Diner, so I was pretty pumped to try it out. Went with my wife for dinner on a cool evening, and we LOVED the feel and environment of the place! So cute and sweet. I love that they have unique comfort food, and aren't afraid of butter or red meat. I got the Big Jim Fried Chicken Biscuit, and it was seriously fantastic. I'm a big guy, and I couldn't even finish it, but every bite was awesome. Would definitely recommend going, and we will be back for sure!

Had to update my review to share that I had dinner here last weekend for the final day of Arizona Cocktail Week. Of course, I couldn't pass up half priced hurricanes!  I tried the Vegan Po'boy (fried avocado, kale, pico de gallo and chipotle remoulade on french bread) and it was magical...but left me wondering how the heck do you fry avocados? No, seriously??? I'm sure google will tell me later which will lead to fun experiments in the kitchen....   Customer service is top notch--everyone that works here is super friendly and the wait time for food wasn't too shabby. I really love the vibe of this place and predict many visits in the future. Day or night, this place is one of the top restaurants in Phoenix.

This was definitely a fun place to check out! It felt very unique and what I imagined to be representative of the community.  It was fun that all the seating was outside. I wasn't very interested in their drink options... but they did have a great selection of food items. I got the fish po'boy sandwich. The main problem I had with this was how much liquid came out. Once I picked it up a puddle soon developed on my plate and if I put my sandwich down it would get soggy. Well after holding it for a extended period of time with the juices running down my arms, and watching my husband eat all the fries, I finally put it down to grab a few. So then the bottom of my sandwich became extremely soggy. But the fish was still very good. And the sauce they gave us for the fries was also very good! I just wish their cups had been bigger.

Sort of a novelty, very unique, very small...this place does burgers and a quick lunch very well.  Not suggesting bring all your friends becaue the space is limited but for a quick bite to eat, this place is suitable.

If I was on death row and had one last meal... this would have to be it. Welcome Diner offers hands down the most hearty, homey, savory, authentic food in Phoenix. My favorites include the Big Jim (chicken biscuit w/ gravy + bacon) and the PB&B. But everything is great. Awesome atmosphere and employees, can't ask for anything more. If you like this place, try Welcome Chicken and Donuts!

This is a long overdue update. I don't think it gets much better than the Welcome diner. This place is legit delicious, I would struggle to find a meal I have had here that was sub par.... And I've been here many times (more than my check ins reflect). I try to bring people here as often as possible, family, friends... Because it is just that good. My favorite time to come is brunch..... One of the guys who works behind the counter gave me official credit for ordering the sunrise sandwich with egg over medium add tomato confit.... Add the confit... You will not be sorry. This thing is better than the lux egg sandwich (and if you know me, you know that's a big deal). The egg is always cooked perfectly, the biscuits are always buttery, flaky, and wonderful. The sandwich is the right mix of decadent and fresh.... Oh and if the husband gets the biscuits and gravy.... Put a little gravy on that sandwich and it's heavenly. Plus, they give you real cream for your coffee... Did you hear me? Heavy fricken cream!!! So good. Make sure you follow these guys on facebook for their beautiful daily specials that you wouldn't find in any other diner in the world (fresh made chicken and dumplings with butter poached chanterelle mushrooms for example). Have the pb and bacon burger... So yummy. Drinks? Forget about it, they are fantastic and happy hour has great specials. Sit inside the diner for great conversation and a bit of a show during your meal. Don't hesitate in trying this place out.

My party and I sat outside. The tables and dish ware were clean and the atmosphere was very fun and pleasant. The staff was kind and helpful. I had the Hurricane cocktail and it was phenomenal. I also had the Fire Bird and the beignets. The Fire Bird was good, but the beignets were amazing. My party also had the mac and cheese and grilled cheese, and they said they were delicious. Definitely coming back to try more. Love that they cater to the late night crowd; one of the few places.
Amazing.... had big Jim. Dope! The hurricanes are awesome too. Could have used little more rum.  Finished it off with beignets with honey and powder sugar...  I'm in coma now! :)

I've never felt so compelled to use expletives in a review, but I feel like I could cuss up a storm and still not quite convey how much I'm digging Welcome Diner.   I've been here three times, twice in the past week, and I can't wait to go again. I had the holy puerco on my first visit, the big Jim on my second, and today I had the Carol with cheese, bacon, and egg added at the suggestion of the guy taking our order. Everything has been utterly impeccable. It's comfort food at its absolute finest. I can't wait to make it through their entire menu and I have absolute confidence that I'll find many more delicious gems just waiting to be devoured.   The atmosphere and location couldn't be any better either. Sitting outside on a nice wintry Phoenix day in Garfield will no doubt yield some good people watching and you'll be thankful to just be where you are.   In closing, I want to thank these folks for doing what they're doing. If you haven't been here yet, or if you're for some silly reason on the fence about giving it a shot, stop deliberating and get your tail over there. You'll be happy you did.

I forgot to review this little diamond in the rough when I was there in August, but I LOVED it! Super fun atmosphere inside and out, deLUSCIOUS comfort food, and great drinks made by happy staff make this a sweet stop! I'm originally from Alabama. Let me tell you; I had the Fried Chicken Mac n Cheese, and it is Deep South approved!

The ambiance at Welcome Diner is excellent for the location and neighborhood it is in.  Nestled on the Northwest corner of 10th St. and Roosevelt, it is a perfect fit for this Garfield gem!  The service is always great, consistent and on point.  I would call the overall genre of  the food to be southern, comfort food with a modern twist.  The standouts that I've tried thus far are the PB&B Burger and the Big Jim.  The handcrafted libations are all done very well and they are not shy with their pours!  It comes as no surprise to me that this business is thriving and growing!  All day happy hour on Tuesdays.  Check it out when you're in the hood or downtown!
This place is amazing. Food is next level and so is the service. Rob was awesome. That is all
Very friendly service and one of the best burgers that I have had in a very long time.

I trekked all the way to this place from the Convention Center.  I was a little unsure if I was headed to the right place, since Welcome Diner is located in a neighborhood, but I'm so glad that I found it.  My food was delicious and the staff seemed genuinely friendly and interested in how I thought that the food was, which is always the sign of a good chef.  I did have to wait a little bit, but I didn't mind too much, since it's a small establishment.  People should be forewarned that there is very limited seating indoors and that most of the seating is outdoors on the patio.  I personally thought that it was nice to sit outside, especially with the mural on painted on the fence/wall, but I understand that it might not be so comfortable to sit outside at the picnic tables in extremely hot Phoenix weather, especially if it was a busy day and you had to share a bench/table with a bunch of people you don't know.  I got a fried green tomato sandwich on sourdough with house-made corn salsa and arugula.  It was fantastically delicious.  The ingredients were fresh and everything from the toasting of the bread to the battering of the tomatoes was well-executed.  Although the sandwich was filling and came with a slice of cantaloupe, I wish that it had come with some sort of side, like home-made potato chips, for the price.  Alongside my sandwich, I had a tasty Four Peaks stout.
Perfect hole in the wall Diner with awesome friendly service and some awesome soul food to back it up. everything on the menu is amazing! go see it and experiance it for yourself. it's truly unique.

There are some good things about this place and definitely some bad things. The poutine fries where really good. The fried chicken biscuit was good but only after I pulled the chicken out of it. The chicken itself was really tough and disgusting, luckily it slid out of the breading really easily. It would be nice if they used some sort of number system instead of screaming names every time they come outside with food or drinks, that would also eliminate the borderline awkwardness of the guy at the counter who asks for names. Last but not least of things I didn't like about this place which I know they cannot help is the other customers!!! One guy had an aggressive dog that almost bit some kid, there was another group of young 20 somethings that took out table even though we had full waters and napkins on it and there where 7 other open spots, then the other group on the other side of the family style table that was making some borderline offensive comments..... so needless to say after being around rude undesirable hipsters of all ages I probably won't be coming back. The staff was pretty friendly though and I really do love like 75% of their concept.

Meh.  This place is more funky cool than good food.  I went there for late happy hour with a friend.   The first thing to know is the inside seating is limited to the bar, maybe 6 seats.  You order outside and sit at patio tables.   The staff is super friendly.   The drinks are great.   Everything is expensive.  We ordered 2 hurricanes, poutine, brussel sprouts & mac & cheese appetizers  $42.00 plus feeding the tip jar.  The drinks were fantastic.  There was nothing good about the poutine; super skinny fries with 2 slices of cheddar cheese and a heap of lukewarm, flavorless,  really heavy sausage gravy.   Brussel sprouts were ok; roasted with what seemed like no seasoning.  Mac & cheese was a heavy glob without a lot of flavor.  Best advice, stick to the drinks.

The hubby was the one who read the reviews before choosing this place so I didn't really know what to expect. I knew we would be eating outside and the ambiance is really nice- backyard and picnicky. The food is more fancy and upscale. The Mac n cheese is thick and creamy. My daughter wasn't really into it. The brisket on the fries was really good and tender but I didn't care for their slaw.  Yelp mentions it is a good place for kids and maybe it is during the day. We are traveling and are way off our routine. We came around 10 at night with a 4 year old. Don't do that lol. (Don't judge , she was fine, just off a 3 hour "nap" with her daddy who is recovering from night shift Army stuff). Anyway, the crowd is young and language was vulgar from multiple tables.   It really is a nice little place to sit under the stars on a nice night, enjoy a drink or two with your SO or friends. The kiddos can skip this one.

Just get the Welcome Burger...I've had me a lot of burgers in Phoenix.  This one takes the cake!  Also, I recommend giving their homebrewed ginger beer a shot!  I promise you won't regret it.  I can't stop thinking about that burger!
Unique dishes, with quality ingredients. Great laid back atmosphere. Had a great time!

Great people and amazing food.   A cute place with a great patio.   Indoor seating is very limited with only about 10 seats at the counter.   We had the fried green tomato sandwich and loaded Mac n cheese.   Food was exceptional.    We will return!

Welcome diner is so cute and quirky. They have very limited indoor seating but have plenty of space on their patio. Try the mac'n'cheese or a burger. They also have a great selection of craft beer. It feels like you're at a picnic.

After years of being vacant, it's nice to see the Welcome Diner property revived. I'm impressed by the caliber of the menu that Michael has put together. And I love how there is Southern and Cajun style food. But even I couldn't have imagined something like the Holy Puerco--cheddar grit cake with cracklins and pulled pork. I also like the kale sandwich with the fried avocado. If you're getting the avocado, split it with a friend. Five pieces of that is a lot, in my opinion.  The biscuits are really unique. You can taste a difference from theirs and what you may get at another restaurant. The biscuit sandwich with the fried chicken and honey will hit just the right spot. I also like the biscuit with goat cheese and jam. And we can't forget about the peanut butter + bacon burger with fries. You may get some clogged arteries from sampling everything but it may just be worth it. I urge people to try this place. I'm sure it's only a matter of time before Guy Fieri parachutes in.   I ended up writing about this place for an article on restaurants worth highlighting in Phoenix. Besides the food, I think this has a terrific location to build on being the "Cheers" of the Garfield neighborhood. The patio is really inviting and you can watch residents coming and going since it's in a residential area. It is quite hipster-dominated but that's just what a lot of Garfield and the Roosevelt Row area are. Hopefully there will be people to welcome this place for a long time to come.

I tried this place for the first time this weekend and I'm so glad I did! I stumbled there with my bf after a house party in the neighborhood and we decided to eat and sober up before we left. I had the sunrise breakfast sandwich with sourdough (they were out of biscuits) and bacon mac & cheese. The sandwich was surprisingly really good without the biscuit I think I'll get it with bread everytime! The mac & cheese is heavenly!! The only gripe I had was that took a while for food to get to us. But I understand since we came right before closing they were a good amount people there already. So if you're ever drunk I'm the area and need some sobering up food I highly recommend!!

Was my first time there...I loved it! ! I got the big jim I think..it was biscuits and gravy bacon and fried chicken! !! Mmmm delicious! ! Also ordered the hurricane drink during happy hour it was 6$ such a summer refreshing drink! !

My 16 year-old son and I were already downtown and starving, so we decided to give WD a try. It was only 4:30 on a Friday, and they don't open until 5 pm, so we just cruised around the neighborhood for a little while to kill time. We walked up right as they opened (in fact, we were the first people there, other than a young lady ordering take out from the window). I wasn't sure how it all worked, not having been before, and didn't know that there is indoor seating, so we were prepared to sit at one of the tables out front. The cheery guy sticking his head out of the take-out window invited us in, to our relief (It was kind of chilly outside). We took the bar stools at the farthest end from the door. But with the music speaker directly behind our heads and in the path of a vigorously blowing fan, we weren't in the most comfortable spot. But before we could decide whether or not to move (I mean a couple of minutes!), every seat was taken and a long line of people was queuing up out front at the take-out window. So we stayed put and waited to order.  As I noted, we were the first people to arrive, so I was a tad annoyed that it took so long to place my drink order (two other customers' orders were  taken before mine, so I also had a bit of a wait for my Manhattan, which was delicious; still, the bartender needs to work on his speed of execution--I tended bar for several years, and besides not paying attention to taking orders in order of the customers' arrival, he was slow and a bit fumbly).  While we were sitting there waiting to order food, Mr. Cheerful came over to show us diners the evening's special: chicken and sausage gumbo. He explained that it had a southwest twist--nopalitas instead of okra, which makes sense, because getting fresh okra right now is not an option (which is why gumbo made in the winter traditionally includes fil powder--or if it's a seafood gumbo, roux. Nowadays, though, you're likely to find any combination of okra, fil, and/or roux. I was told that WD's gumbo just used a roux.). The little squares of nopalitas added a delicious flavor and texture, and if you didn't tell someone otherwise, they'd never guess they were eating cactus paddles.  Anyway, I was intrigued. I grew up in the South and have spent a fair amount of time in Louisiana, so I consider myself well-versed on this dish that I often make myself--although during this season of Lent, one is more apt to find gumbo z'erbes on home tables than the version with meat). Plus, I was freezing because of the fan, so a steaming bowl of gumbo sounded perfect.  And it was, although I had to ask for a spoon so I could eat it.  A  couple of dashes of  hot sauce,  and it was so, so good. I could've easily eaten a second serving! Speaking of seconds, my son loved his Little Birdy biscuit sandwich so much that when he finished it, he asked if he could have another. Hah! Well, it was that good. The biscuit is tender and crumbly (and huge), and we are a biscuit-crazy family, but the chicken was the real star. Seriously addictive stuff. We also ordered a bowl of the mac 'n cheese, which was a very generous portion of pasta drenched in a sauce containing a hint of smokiness (from smoked Gouda, I suspect). I found it a bit flat (underseasoned) and disappointing. The "herbs" seemed to amount to a sad sprinkling of chives that did nothing except add a dash of color, and the cheese sauce tasted more of bechamel than cheese. As my son commented, "This can't hold a candle to your friend Bernie's mac and cheese at Citizen." Agreed. One more note about the dish: while it's definitely fun to watch someone in the tiny kitchen whip out a blow torch and pass it over a dish, it doesn't really add anything to this one (at least not ours). The result was a scattering of blackened spots across the top, rather than creating a bubbly, browned top. If there'd been a sprinkling of cheese to torch, then I'd see the point. But as it is? Nope.  We wound up taking most of it home, and I'll doctor the leftovers up myself. After we stuffed ourselves on dinner, my son unbelievably still had room for dessert. Of course, we ordered beignets. Ok, bear with this picky foodie for a second: these fried donuts served in a pool of really, really good honey and powdered sugar were delicious. But beignets? They looked like beignets. They smelled like beignets. But these little fried gems are dense rather than the slightly chewy, airy pillows I expected. I don't think they used a choux pastry or let it rise long enough.  In any case, don't expect real beignets and you'll happily enjoy them!  We look forward to returning to WD, although we plan to hit their sister joint Welcome CHICKEN + DONUTS first. I'll post something here when we do.
The food, service, and overall vibe of this place were fantastic. They had great ginger beer made in house and phenomenal chicken biscuits. Everything my group had was good and we left super stuffed.

DUDE. Gnarliest food. EVER. We stopped here on our way back from phoenix to California. Hubs had the carol, coleslaw, and fries and I had the watermelon,  tomato and arugula salad. OMG. Every BITE had flavor. Wayne. .is it wayne? Dude, I don't even know but he was super hospitable and welcoming and great all around. The food was out of this world.yum.dude. LOVE.

This is my favorite spot near downtown the food is sooo good the atmosphere is so cool everyone there is super nice and did I mention the food? Their friend green tomato sandwich is To die for and their pulled pork fries are addicting!
If you need a cheat day, take a cheat day here and get their Mac N Cheese! It is to die for!! All their food is amazing!!

First time today and overall impressed. This is apparently their new location and it really nice. Good amount of indoor and outdoor seating and the decor is nice. The staff was friendly and the waiter, Marcus, was very informative about the menu. He recommended the burgers/sandwiches but since it was late was looking for a something a bit lighter so I ended up getting the jambalaya. My bf ordered the Big Jim which is a biscuit sandwich and he really enjoyed that. My jambalaya was ok, I was expecting something more runny. BUT what really blew me away and the reason I did 5 stars is their house made ginger beer!! SUPERB  I could sip on this all day. Next time, I will try their hamburger/sandwich since that's what they are more know for and skip the jambalaya. That ginger beer tho  can't wait for next time!

Food is delicious!! We were not aware there was an inside until halfway through our visit, but sitting outside under the misters was just fine!  I had the pulled pork fries and some poutine! Both were delicious!! The pulled pork has somes mustardy type sauce on it that is quite unusual but good!  The poutine is made with a white gravy and American cheese instead of the traditional brown gravy and cheese curds but very delicious and american dinerish.  Would definitely order again! I also had a hurricane, omg, sooo good! Loved it, really fruity and refreshing!!  My friend had the burger that he said was very good!! I look forward to going back and trying more things!

Came here after an evening shift and loved it.  I didn't even know this place existed!  Such a cool idea... an old-fashioned diner serving late-night comfort food and cocktails.  It was super refreshing sitting outside in the air sipping a Paloma (grapefruit jarritos combined with tequila and some sort of juice) and munching on a side of fries.  Some of the other people in my group got biscuits, which looked incredible.  We hung out until closing-time, at which point a waiter wandered out to give us a few "hey, closing soon" friendly reminders.  We told him he should probably change the sign to "UNwelcome diner" at closing time every night.  He decided "nah man, that's not our vibe."  Too funny.  Love the service.  This is definitely going to be one of my late-night post-shift haunts.

The welcome dinner was the first places my friend brought me. That was a few years ago and I went again recently. Still an amazing place.  It's a small kitchen, and very popular, so expect a bit of a wait. The seating is relaxed and inviting. The din of the eating area is perfect, as it is outside. Great place to come and lay back for awhile or before going into first Friday that is just down the street.   I suggest the ginger beer, it's house brewed and delicious! Any drink with it was not a let down (I had a few) I also had the honey biscuit sandwich and tried the free tomato also. Everything I've tried here is tasty.
Was delicious ! Big Jim, poutine fries,  beignets... now I need to try some more items!!
Food took wayyyyyy too long. Takes forever to get food and is not worth it. Spend your late baker dollars at McDonald's

My new favorite place! Great flavorful food (sausage gravy is peppery and delicious). Drinks were perfect and atmosphere is casual. Perfect for kicking back on the porch and hanging with friends.  Daughter and I shared Mac and cheese (perfect, creamy, tangy) and the grilled cheese (minus the tomato confit). Intimate, unassuming location in a residential corner.

Bravo! This place aced it for me. I always like to read what people order at places to help me decide. I guarantee that anything you order here will be amazing and delicious. Great job guys!! Makes me happy to see a spot like this in Phoenix. Reminds me of Portland. Things are lookin up for the foodie scene.
Great food, great people. Highly recommended for  community oriented, easy going individuals who also enjoy good a Americana meal.

What a perfect rescue for the social late night meal. My wife and I sat at the bar tonight and were greeted by Chadwick, a friendly bartender who offered us beer tastings and walked us through the menu in great detail. You could tell he really knew and loved the food they had to offer. The cocktail list was creative and had me wishing I had ordered one too! The poutine was the best I've ever had and we had this open-faced sandwich that I'm still dreaming about. Very friendly place, great vibes, and great atmosphere. We'll be back soon!

I would religiously talk about how great this place was....tonight june 13 was off!!! Our biscuits came out burnt....sent back...good brought back the sandwich was super salty....fries with gravy cold the cheese stuck it all together....tell the waiter he's says....it's you!!!!45.90bill for three biscuit chickens and it's me???!!!! What a bad experience and customer service was less than one star!!!! I'm sorry welcome back diner but me and my friends family won't be back#!!!!! Hire employees that actually care!

This place is great atmosphere and delicious food!  Bring a coat in the fall/winter if you are eating outside because it can get fairly cold.  Also, if you go there on First Friday be expected to wait about an hour for you food.   The Blue Sky burger is off the chain.

Great food, great drinks, great atmosphere, AND a great staff! Say whaaaaaaaaaat?!?!?    I had a brief, but torrid affair with the grilled cheese, and that delicious SOB left me wanting more!    I HIGHLY recommend this spot!!!
Our daughter recommended this spot. And good thing she did, PERFECT BURGER! we will be back again and again.  Plus, it's a super charming, out of place, random, cool & hipster setting/location. Love!

I am going to hold total  judgement on this hippy hangout but be warned: check the prices BEFORE you go.  Two tiny  biscuit orders and gravy fries will set you back $30 and then add a drink with tip and tax you will be out $40.  I mean really.  Nice  place for skinny females who eat like a bird but if you are a construction worker who wolfs down 3 Big Macks, fries, and jumbo  soda at the burger stand, eating like that here will cost you a weeks pay.

I almost never write reviews,  but this needed one. There used to be a vegan ace in LA called pure luck. Had this bbq jackfruit sandwich that I loved. It went out of business a while ago and I haven't found one like it since. Until last night. That jackfruit po'boy was amazing. One of the best sandwiches I've ever had. My hat is off.  Honestly, might even be worth a drive from la, just for the sandwich.

I live a couple blocks from this place and I would literally eat here every day if I could afford to.  Though I'd probably end up with a few extra pounds to go with my empty bank account.  But every day when they post their daily special up on their Facebook page, I just sit and drool over it.  I've eaten here a handful of times and everything is so freaking good.  Its comfort food at its best.  And the staff is super friendly and helpful.  They treat you like a regular even if its your first time.  I love the fact that they source all their ingredients from local farmers and purveyors.  I initially thought the prices were a bit on the high side, but once I realized just how well the locally sourced ingredients were prepared, I now feel like its a bargain.  And I also love that they are open until midnight every day (except Monday).  This is just the coolest little place to grab some great food, a good drink, and chill with really friendly people.  I hope this place is around for a very long time.
Cool place! Great vibe and nice people working there! Ginger beer was REALLY good! Will be coming back and bringing friends!
I was in town for a graduation and my daughter found this place on yelp and I'm glad she did. The atmosphere was great and the food was excellent. Best time I had in Phoenix

PB&B was surprisingly delicious! I would have never thought peanut butter on a burger would be delicious, but it's super tasty!! Their fries are crispy and taste like real potato. The second generation cocktail is really good and I can drink those all day!

Great food at OK prices, with a laid-back al fresco slash in-your-own-backyard set up. Even during the peak of summer, the outdoor misters make it a comfy spot to grub and hang.   Only reason why I'm not giving it another star is because the two very separate occasions that I phoned in a pick-up order, this girl would take my order - and I don't know if it's just how her voice sounds (???) - but she just makes you feel like you shouldn't be asking questions. Mega rude, that one.

LOVE THIS PLACE MAN.   Such a unique menu and drink selection.   The vibes are strong. I got the PB and B Burger and it was heavenly. I also tried my buddy's biscuit with chicken and gravy and that was divine.   This is a great place to hang with friends and eat delicious food.   BB's Rating: Rooseveltastic!

The stars are really for the location, set up and atmosphere. The seating is first come first serve which isn't a lot, they have 3 massive tables that can be shared unless a huge party is there and just sit to chat for a couple of hours. Seemed as though the kitchen was understaffed, took forever for our food. The menu is super small, burgers, salads and every which way for biscuits and gravy. The burger was okay, it was a burger. It wasn't special or even that flavorful. I ordered a side of Brussels instead of fries (I know, who does that) after a long wait they bring out burger & fries, we tell the server and he takes my entire plate, brings back just the burger. 5 minutes later the Brussels come out. They were black. Fully burned.  If I returned it would be to take up seating, wasn't impressed by the food or the fact they take your whole plate back just to return the one piece. Did they reuse the fries?
This place is freaking awesome. Burger is on point. It's outside and you will probably have to wait a little bit, but trust me, it is worth the wait!

I go to Welcome Diner so much at this point, I feel like making up disguises. It's like, c'mon, I'm JUST trying eat here everyday of my life and not feel embarrassed about it.   The thing is, they make the best everything I've ever had anywhere.  The Bleu Burger? Omg. The Peanut Butter Bacon Burger? Literally so good, I'm pretty sure I lost IQ points. The Biscuit Sandwiches? I want to be in a Facebook-official relationship with one.  Just go here - you will understand and you will not regret it. Actually, you might regret it, because you tend to go.. no where else afterwards. Just start trying your disguises on now.  Real complaint: They only do breakfast on weekends, doesn't start till 10:30am. More real complaint: They won't let me move in.

You know that place you always say you want to go to, but never get around to actually going? Welcome Diner was that place for me. Someone would mention it and, mentally, I'd make a note to make it over there but that swiftly slipped my mind. Until recently, when my buddy Paul wanted to get out for dinner. And enter Welcome Diner.  The weather was great for our meal, maybe a little chilly. Paul ordered the fish po'boy and a side of poutine (the latter we shared), I ordered the Garfield (which was previously on the menu, then taken off, because it was announced on the board as such) with an over-easy egg. The spicy fried kale was fantastic. However, eating this as a sandwich was messy--I had yolk and juices dripping which resulted in me licking my hands and arms like the dog in the corner. There was a dog in the corner; we were on the patio. So, I took the top biscuit off and finished it with a fork and knife.   Paul said he enjoyed the po'boy, but we both agreed what they called poutine wasn't poutine. It was fries with shredded cheese melted over it and white gravy. Not bad, really, but not the poutine we've had.  So now that I've *finally* made it here, I know now I'll be back again and again. Thx, Paul!

Quaint little diner - a great example of kitschy 50s Americana. It's the sort of thing 5 & Diner tries to be, only more authentic. The menu is very simple and it's nothing you couldn't get elsewhere, but the food is very good. You didn't really come here for the food though, did you... no, you came here for the atmosphere...  I went during the summer and it was pretty hot inside the little box. There were some fans working overtime to help compensate, but with the cramped quarters, the dining area is pretty close to the stove.   You can tell that for the people that own and operate this joint, it's definitely a labor of love. It's such a warm and inviting place to go. I can see eating here once in awhile for the experience, but it's not the kind of place I could see myself eating regularly... maybe it's because I don't live in the neighborhood. People in walking distance would definitely become addicted to the place.   I really enjoyed the food here. There were funny little books available for us to read and there was a notebook where customers could draw in. The whole thing was something I'll always remember... fondly. You owe it to yourself to at least check this place out once.

I met my friend here for dinner and hadn't really head of this place even though I don't work too far away from the Garfield location. To be honest I'm not too keen on eating outdoors, especially when it's so hot outside. They do have limited seating inside but they were all occupied.  It took me a while to decide what I wanted to try and I ended up selecting the jambalaya. This version did not have shrimp, which is something I can eat my weight in, but it was still excellent. The portion was larger than it appeared and I didn't even come close to finishing it.  When I got there, there was maybe one other customer outside. After the sun set, this place was very busy. In fact, I've never seen a crowd like this. This place must be extremely popular.  I'd like to go back, but I think I'll wait until the summer heat subsides a bit.

The place is...quirky (hipster?) And it's mostly outside so remember that in the summer! Everyone we talked to was really nice and the food was great. You can tell they really put passion into the food, even if they're just making you a biscuit sandwich (the guy even pointed out how he hand-made everything on the plate).    A good place to hang when the weather is cooler but I wouldn't take a girl there on a first date.
The biscuits are delicious and made for giants. Like always Welcome Diner kills it again.
This is my favorite place to eat when I'm in AZ. I travel all over the west and this place makes me smile every time. Great local food and the Beers are always legit. A must visit !  Cheers.

So glad I found this place! My friend and I walked over on First Friday after a guy recommended it to us and described it as a place with great "comfort food." It's a few blocks from the more populated, business portion of Roosevelt. Since we were walking at night, it was a little sketchy given it was dark and there were barely any street lights. But the food and service were well worth the 5 minute creepy walk. Plus it made it more of an adventure ;)  This places feels like an outdoor diner, located on a residential block. You order your food at a window and then find a seat outside in the cute little lot. Despite the fact it was First Friday, the wait wasn't long at all. I think this is because, as I mentioned, it's a bit off the main strip of Roosevelt. We were able to easily find a comfortable place to sit and the service was great. I loved how patient the woman taking our order was and her enthusiasm describing their menu :) There's nothing worse than when you're excited to try a new place and the service is lackluster. This woman took her time and even checked on us later once our food arrived.  I tried the crunchy peanut butter, bacon burger with pickles and cheddar cheese. I know, right?! Sounds crazy! It was highly recommended by the person in front of me in line. And just way too weird for me to not try ---and man, am I glad I did! It was SO GOOD! The flavors actually really complimented each other, especially the saltiness of the peanut butter/bacon and sweetness of the peanut butter/pickles. The bun was also fantastic and fresh. Descent beef portion too. It came with a side of fries which were cooked to perfection.   I will definitely be returning. There are a bunch of other delicious sounding items I'd like to try. A place with a cool, hipster vibe to it and the food, service, and unique menu are outstanding!!

Super cool, eclectic, very old diner from the 1940's. I did not like the burger I got but to be fair I knew it was just me and not them. I got the PB Burger which I am guessing is an acquired taste that I have not yet acquired. Ha! So I wiped off the PB and devoured all the ingredients separately for this review. I was pretty happy with the results. All the ingredients were delish. The burger juicy and tasty. For some reason I was nuts about their pickles. lol. I love pickles but these were extra wonderful to me. I also liked their Brussel Sprouts. Super cool and friendly staff too.

Airbnb did not disappoint. This spot was down the street from the spot I rented and oh man, bombest food in town. Their Champion burger with Mac and cheese was pretty dank. Probably the best burger and Mac and cheese I've had. Also their braised pork with fries was good too. I'm definitely coming back to this spot every time I'm in Phoenix! On top of that, their crew here are pretty entertaining. Pretty hip spot!
Simply said delicious chicken, I'm in love with their mac n cheese, the biscuits make the sandwiches awesome, I'm going to work my way through the entire menu, it all sounds great eats
Yeah... the Green Fried Tomato Sandwich was amazing. Never had anything like this before. The corn relish was delicious and the tomato is breaded and then fried. Too good.
